Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What ethnic groups is the Rwandan society is composed of?
Options: A. Hutu and Tutsi, B. Hutu, Tutsi and Twa, C.  Hutu and Twa
Correct Option: B

Question 2: Approximately how many people died during the Rwandan genocide? Options: A. 400,000, B. 600,000, C. 800,000, D. 1,000,000 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary factor that contributed to the intense political hostility between Hutu and Tutsi in Rwanda? Options: A. Economic inequality, B. Colonial powers' encouragement of political division, C. Cultural differences, D. Historical conflicts Correct Option: B

The Hutu government was overthrown, and Tutsi took control., C. The international community intervened to establish a new government., D. The conflict escalated into a regional war. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What lesson can be learned from the Rwandan genocide regarding international intervention? Options: A. That international intervention is always effective in preventing humanitarian crises., B. That international intervention is never necessary in preventing humanitarian crises., C. That international intervention is crucial in preventing humanitarian crises, but it must be timely and effective., D. That international intervention is only necessary in cases of genocide. Correct Option: B

The challenges of establishing justice and accountability in post-conflict societies., D. The need for formal courts. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What combination of factors contributed to the Rwandan genocide? Options: A. Colonialism, economic inequality, and cultural differences., B. Propaganda, ethnic division, and colonialism., C. Historical conflicts, economic inequality, and international intervention., D. Cultural differences, colonialism, and economic inequality. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What does the experience of Rwanda highlight regarding post-conflict societies? Options: A. The importance of addressing the root causes of conflict and promoting reconciliation and healing., B. The need for international intervention to establish a new government., C. The effectiveness of formal courts in providing justice and accountability., D. The importance of punishing perpetrators. Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is a matter of debate regarding the gacaca courts? Options: A. Their effectiveness in providing justice and accountability., B. Their importance in promoting reconciliation and healing., C. Their role in punishing perpetrators., D. Their impact on international intervention. Correct Option: A
Question 12: How can the international community's response to the genocide be evaluated? Options: A. In terms of its economic impact., B. In terms of its moral and ethical implications., C. In terms of its effectiveness in preventing future genocides., D. In terms of its role in establishing formal courts. Correct Option: B
Question 13: What was the primary reason for the failure of the international community to intervene in the Rwandan genocide? Options: A. Lack of resources, B. Lack of awareness, C. Failure to recognize the severity of the situation, D. Political interests Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the significance of the Rwandan genocide in the context of international relations and global security? Options: A. It highlights the importance of economic development in preventing conflict., B. It demonstrates the need for international intervention in preventing humanitarian crises., C. It shows the impact of colonialism on modern conflicts., D. It emphasizes the importance of addressing the root causes of conflict and promoting reconciliation and healing. Correct Option: D
Question 15: How did the Rwandan government adapt the traditional gacaca system to address the aftermath of the genocide? Options: A. By establishing formal courts, B. By using professional attorneys and judges, C. By dividing charges into categories and assigning set penalties, D. By relying solely on international intervention Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent, I can suggest a few generated MCQs that are somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the ethnic groups that comprise Rwandan society. While there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, some questions do mention the ethnic groups or the divisions between them.

One possible match could be Question 9, which mentions "ethnic division" as a factor contributing to the Rwandan genocide. However, this question does not directly ask about the ethnic groups that comprise Rwandan society.

Another possible match could be Question 7, which discusses the relationship between colonialism and the Rwandan genocide, mentioning the creation of ethnic divisions and tensions. Again, this question does not directly ask about the ethnic groups.

Since there isn't a direct match, I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that is closest in content and intent. In this case, I would suggest Question 9 as the closest match, although it is not a perfect match.

the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In order to come to terms with the past, village tribunal called gacaca, which translates ___________, were set up .
Options: A. Justice in the grass, B. Fair trials for all, C. The truth shall heal, D. End to Impunity
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Over the course of 10 years, how many individuals were convicted?
Options: A. 100.000, B. 800.000, C. 1.7 million, D. 3 million
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When solar cells were first invented in the 1950s, what was the cost the electricity they produced?
Options: A. $100/Watt, B. $200/Watt, C. $300/Watt, D. $400/Watt
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When did Bell Laboratories introduce the first commercially sold solar cell? Options: A. 1940, B. 1954, C. 1960, D. 1970 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the average consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit in the US in 2022? Options: A. $10,000 to $15,000, B. $17,000 to $23,000, C. $25,000 to $30,000, D. $35,000 to $40,000 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What impact did the Renewable Energy Sources Act have on the solar energy market? Options: A. It decreased demand for solar panels, leading to reduced production., B. It created unprecedented demand for solar panels worldwide, leading to increased production and innovation., C. It had no significant impact on the solar energy market., D. It led to a temporary increase in solar panel prices. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a key benefit of rooftop solar units? Options: A. They increase reliance on fossil fuels., B. They reduce reliance on fossil fuels and pave the way for a cleaner energy future., C. They have no impact on the environment., D. They are only beneficial for large-scale energy production. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What can governments do to drive the adoption of solar energy? Options: A. Implement policies and incentives, like the Renewable Energy Sources Act., B. Increase the cost of solar panels., C. Decrease the production of solar panels., D. Provide no support for solar energy adoption. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How can homeowners benefit from investing in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. By increasing their energy bills., B. By reducing their energy bills and contributing to a cleaner energy future., C. By having no impact on their energy bills., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the increased demand for solar panels and the decrease in prices? Options: A. The increased demand led to an increase in prices., B. The increased demand had no impact on prices., C. The increased demand led to a decrease in prices due to economies of scale and innovation., D. The decreased demand led to a decrease in prices. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the initial cost of solar cells in 1954 compare to the current cost of rooftop solar units? Options: A. The initial cost was lower than the current cost., B. The initial cost was significantly higher than the current cost., C. The initial cost was the same as the current cost., D. There is no contrast between the two costs. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is a potential new model for making solar energy more accessible? Options: A. Combining community-based solutions with solar leasing models., B. Implementing policies to increase the cost of solar panels., C. Decreasing the production of solar panels., D. Focusing solely on large-scale solar farms. Correct Option: A
Question 10: How can rooftop solar units be integrated with larger-scale wind and solar farms? Options: A. By creating a more comprehensive approach to decarbonizing the energy grid., B. By increasing the reliance on fossil fuels., C. By having no impact on the energy grid., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the effectiveness of the Renewable Energy Sources Act be evaluated? Options: A. By assessing the increase in fossil fuel consumption., B. By evaluating the decrease in solar panel prices and the increase in solar adoption., C. By analyzing the increase in energy bills., D. By justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels based on potential savings alone. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a key consideration for justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. The potential increase in energy bills., B. The potential decrease in energy bills and contribution to a cleaner energy future., C. The aesthetic appeal of solar panels., D. The potential decrease in fossil fuel consumption alone. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The initial cost was significantly higher than the current cost., C. The initial cost was the same as the current cost., D. There is no contrast between the two costs. Correct Option: B**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working

to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In many countries, solar energy is the cheapest form of electricity. Cheaper, even, than fossil fuel generated electricity.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When did Bell Laboratories introduce the first commercially sold solar cell? Options: A. 1940, B. 1954, C. 1960, D. 1970 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the average consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit in the US in 2022? Options: A. $10,000 to $15,000, B. $17,000 to $23,000, C. $25,000 to $30,000, D. $35,000 to $40,000 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What impact did the Renewable Energy Sources Act have on the solar energy market? Options: A. It decreased demand for solar panels, leading to reduced production., B. It created unprecedented demand for solar panels worldwide, leading to increased production and innovation., C. It had no significant impact on the solar energy market., D. It led to a temporary increase in solar panel prices. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a key benefit of rooftop solar units? Options: A. They increase reliance on fossil fuels., B. They reduce reliance on fossil fuels and pave the way for a cleaner energy future., C. They have no impact on the environment., D. They are only beneficial for large-scale energy production. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What can governments do to drive the adoption of solar energy? Options: A. Implement policies and incentives, like the Renewable Energy Sources Act., B. Increase the cost of solar panels., C. Decrease the production of solar panels., D. Provide no support for solar energy adoption. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How can homeowners benefit from investing in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. By increasing their energy bills., B. By reducing their energy bills and contributing to a cleaner energy future., C. By having no impact on their energy bills., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the increased demand for solar panels and the decrease in prices? Options: A. The increased demand led to an increase in prices., B. The increased demand had no impact on prices., C. The increased demand led to a decrease in prices due to economies of scale and innovation., D. The decreased demand led to a decrease in prices. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the initial cost of solar cells in 1954 compare to the current cost of rooftop solar units? Options: A. The initial cost was lower than the current cost., B. The initial cost was significantly higher than the current cost., C. The initial cost was the same as the current cost., D. There is no contrast between the two costs. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is a potential new model for making solar energy more accessible? Options: A. Combining community-based solutions with solar leasing models., B. Implementing policies to increase the cost of solar panels., C. Decreasing the production of solar panels., D. Focusing solely on large-scale solar farms. Correct Option: A
Question 10: How can rooftop solar units be integrated with larger-scale wind and solar farms? Options: A. By creating a more comprehensive approach to decarbonizing the energy grid., B. By increasing the reliance on fossil fuels., C. By having no impact on the energy grid., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the effectiveness of the Renewable Energy Sources Act be evaluated? Options: A. By assessing the increase in fossil fuel consumption., B. By evaluating the decrease in solar panel prices and the increase in solar adoption., C. By analyzing the increase in energy bills., D. By justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels based on potential savings alone. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a key consideration for justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. The potential increase in energy bills., B. The potential decrease in energy bills and contribution to a cleaner energy future., C. The aesthetic appeal of solar panels., D. The potential decrease in fossil fuel consumption alone. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Between 2010 and 2020 what was the change in price for solar panels on homes?
Options: A. Increase of 20%, B. Decrease of 20 %, C. Decrease of 40%, D. Decrease of 60%
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When did Bell Laboratories introduce the first commercially sold solar cell? Options: A. 1940, B. 1954, C. 1960, D. 1970 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the average consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit in the US in 2022? Options: A. $10,000 to $15,000, B. $17,000 to $23,000, C. $25,000 to $30,000, D. $35,000 to $40,000 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What impact did the Renewable Energy Sources Act have on the solar energy market? Options: A. It decreased demand for solar panels, leading to reduced production., B. It created unprecedented demand for solar panels worldwide, leading to increased production and innovation., C. It had no significant impact on the solar energy market., D. It led to a temporary increase in solar panel prices. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a key benefit of rooftop solar units? Options: A. They increase reliance on fossil fuels., B. They reduce reliance on fossil fuels and pave the way for a cleaner energy future., C. They have no impact on the environment., D. They are only beneficial for large-scale energy production. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What can governments do to drive the adoption of solar energy? Options: A. Implement policies and incentives, like the Renewable Energy Sources Act., B. Increase the cost of solar panels., C. Decrease the production of solar panels., D. Provide no support for solar energy adoption. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How can homeowners benefit from investing in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. By increasing their energy bills., B. By reducing their energy bills and contributing to a cleaner energy future., C. By having no impact on their energy bills., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the increased demand for solar panels and the decrease in prices? Options: A. The increased demand led to an increase in prices., B. The increased demand had no impact on prices., C. The increased demand led to a decrease in prices due to economies of scale and innovation., D. The decreased demand led to a decrease in prices. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the initial cost of solar cells in 1954 compare to the current cost of rooftop solar units? Options: A. The initial cost was lower than the current cost., B. The initial cost was significantly higher than the current cost., C. The initial cost was the same as the current cost., D. There is no contrast between the two costs. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is a potential new model for making solar energy more accessible? Options: A. Combining community-based solutions with solar leasing models., B. Implementing policies to increase the cost of solar panels., C. Decreasing the production of solar panels., D. Focusing solely on large-scale solar farms. Correct Option: A
Question 10: How can rooftop solar units be integrated with larger-scale wind and solar farms? Options: A. By creating a more comprehensive approach to decarbonizing the energy grid., B. By increasing the reliance on fossil fuels., C. By having no impact on the energy grid., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the effectiveness of the Renewable Energy Sources Act be evaluated? Options: A. By assessing the increase in fossil fuel consumption., B. By evaluating the decrease in solar panel prices and the increase in solar adoption., C. By analyzing the increase in energy bills., D. By justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels based on potential savings alone. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a key consideration for justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. The potential increase in energy bills., B. The potential decrease in energy bills and contribution to a cleaner energy future., C. The aesthetic appeal of solar panels., D. The potential decrease in fossil fuel consumption alone. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

**Question 7: What is the relationship between the increased demand for solar panels and the decrease in prices?**

However, this question does not directly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question is not present among the generated MCQs, but Question 8 mentions a comparison of costs over time. 

A more suitable match would be a question that directly addresses the percentage change in price over a specific period, which is not present among the generated MCQs.

However, if we had to choose from the existing options, **Question 8: How does the initial cost of solar cells in 1954 compare to the current cost of rooftop solar units?** is not the best match, but **Question 7** is also not a perfect match.

Since there isn't a perfect match, I will choose the question that talks about a decrease in price over time (though not exactly the same period as in the ground truth MCQ).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how much money can a US homeowner save per year by having solar panels?
Options: A. $150, B. $1500, C. $2000, D. $3000
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What impact did the Renewable Energy Sources Act have on the solar energy market? Options: A. It decreased demand for solar panels, leading to reduced production., B. It led to a temporary increase in solar panel prices. Correct Option: B

Correct Option: B

Question 6: How can homeowners benefit from investing in rooftop solar panels? Options: A. By increasing their energy bills., B. By reducing their energy bills and contributing to a cleaner energy future., C. By having no impact on their energy bills., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: B

By increasing the reliance on fossil fuels., C. By having no impact on the energy grid., D. By only benefiting from the aesthetic appeal of solar panels. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the effectiveness of the Renewable Energy Sources Act be evaluated? Options: A. By assessing the increase in fossil fuel consumption., B. By evaluating the decrease in solar panel prices and the increase in solar adoption., C. By analyzing the increase in energy bills., D. By justifying the investment in rooftop solar panels based on potential savings alone. Correct Option: B

The potential decrease in energy bills and contribution to a cleaner energy future., C. The aesthetic appeal of solar panels., D. The potential decrease in fossil fuel consumption alone. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If someone can't afford the upfront cost of installing solar panels, what might be another option for them?
Options: A. Government-owned panels, B. Communal solar panels, C. Solar panel lottery program, D. A solar leasing model
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Welcome to another event
in the Myth Olympics— the eternal arena in which 
creatures and deities from global mythologies
compete for glory. I’m Shamash, the Mesopotamian
god of judgment, and today we’re gathered to witness 
this year’s clash of stunning speed. Keeping track of our racers with me
is last year’s champion, Hermes— the swift-footed messenger
of the Greek gods. Oh, I'm delighted to hang up my
winged sandals today, Shamash. But I am keeping my helmet on because
we are in for a wild ride! It’s true! Almost every mythical tradition
claims one creature as the fastest of them all. From goddesses who run like the wind
to creatures who outstrip every captor, mortals of all cultures are fascinated
by superhuman swiftness. So, Hermes, who are 
this year’s contestants? Well, the Norse gods have sent Sleipnir— son of Loki and the greatest
of Asgard’s steeds. He’s usually spotted gallivanting
between the realms with Odin. But today, Sleipnir is riding solo. Also competing is Raiju, the Japanese
beast of thunder and lightning. When the weather’s nice, they like
to nap in mortals’ belly buttons. But when clouds darken, Raiju leaps
into action alongside Raijin, the Shinto god of storms. With this fearsome competitor,
lightning can strike at any time. But storms don’t scare Idaten. This Buddhist deity has a record
of outrunning the weather— his name is even part of the Japanese
expression for “run like the wind.” Idaten’s definitely got some tricks
up those steel sleeves. Perhaps, but our last competitor
has tricks of his own. Savitar is the Hindu deity
that sets everything in motion, from moving the Sun
to chasing away sorrow and sickness. Yes, today’s roster contains many
mythic interpretations of speed. From personifications 
of the unpredictable elements to creatures capable of outrunning
reality itself. But perhaps the myth of speed
is really about the elusive nature of all supernatural beings. Those are some, uh, neat ideas, Shamash—
but this race is the real deal! Our noble competitors will run
the equivalent of 100 marathons through a hazardous
natural obstacle course. And our racers are taking 
their first steps right now! Idaten takes the lead, but don’t let
that calm exterior fool you— his determination is legendary. When a literal speed demon stole
one of Buddha's teeth, he raced over mountains and rivers
to capture the culprit. Don’t forget Sleipnir— 
he’s cleared hurdles in his time, too. I’ll say! On his mission to retrieve
Baldur the Bright from the fortress of Hel,
he rode for nine days straight— clearing the gates of the underworld
without breaking a sweat. They don’t call him
the sliding one for nothing— he appears to slide on the wind itself! Of course, wind is often personified
as a sacred being that— No time for a history lesson!
That wind is picking up! Like the force of nature they are, Raiju
brews a storm to scorch the competition. It’s certainly possible. Raiju is known
for their destructive storms. But they’re also our most chaotic racer, frequently crashing to earth and 
getting tangled in flimsy mortal nets. They’re unpredictable! Chaos is often associated
with mythology’s fastest creatures, from the shapeshifting Flemish Kludde
who preys on travelers to the smelly Japanese spirit Nuppeppō
who moves too fast to be caught. True, but there are also steady agents
of speed. Here comes one now! Lending his boundless energy to the Sun,
Savitar breaks through Raiju’s storm! This golden-handed protector of the
universe can manipulate the elements— and all moving things for that matter! A valiant effort to redirect the wind
by Idaten... but not valiant enough. The path seems clear for Savitar. But is that the gallop of hooves I hear? What beautiful blindside! It’s Sleipnir hurtling 
out of another dimension! it seems the shamanic steed shares Odin’s
ability to travel between the realms. This racer might not have to play
by Savitar’s rules. But... wait a second,
am I watching this in slow motion? No! It appears the god of motion is
slowing the speed of his opponent, suspending him centimeters
from the course’s conclusion. Sleipnir’s stampede slows
to a snail’s pace as Savitar leisurely glides
over the finish line! What a finale! Savitar’s mastery of motion
immobilized his fastest foe! It seems Sleipnir’s not too happy
with this controversial result, but hey, there’s always next year. And one might say that we’re all winners
for witnessing the mind-bending speed of so many myths and legends.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is Sleipnir’s father?
Options: A. Thor, B. Odin, C. Loki, D. Hermod
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the Mesopotamian god of judgment? Options: A. Shamash, B. Hermes, C. Savitar, D. Loki Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is Raiju in Japanese mythology? Options: A. The god of thunder, B. The beast of thunder and lightning, C. The god of lightning, D. The messenger of the gods Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main concept that is personified in various mythologies and associated with supernatural beings? Options: A. Power, B. Speed, C. Wisdom, D. Strength Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the Myth Olympics, and what is its purpose? Options: A. A gathering of creatures and deities from global mythologies to discuss their powers, B. An event where creatures and deities from global mythologies compete for glory, C. A ceremony to honor the gods of different mythologies, D. A conference to discuss the importance of mythology Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can the concept of speed in mythology be applied to real-world scenarios? Options: A. By using mythological creatures as mascots for athletic teams, B. By studying the unique abilities of mythological creatures to develop new technologies, C. By applying the idea of supernatural beings with extraordinary abilities to creative writing or storytelling, D. By using mythological themes to promote products Correct Option: C
Question 6: What theme from the Myth Olympics can be applied to various aspects of life, such as business or politics? Options: A. The importance of teamwork, B. The power of love and compassion, C. The theme of competition and rivalry, D. The value of honesty and integrity Correct Option: C
Question 7: What relationship is explored in the Myth Olympics between two contrasting qualities? Options: A. Speed and agility, B. Speed and chaos, C. Power and wisdom, D. Strength and strategy Correct Option: B
Question 8: What contrast is highlighted between two types of competitors in the Myth Olympics? Options: A. Between steady agents of speed and unpredictable creatures, B. Between strong and weak competitors, C. Between fast and slow competitors, D. Between old and young competitors Correct Option: A
Question 9: What unique narrative is created by combining different mythological traditions and creatures? Options: A. A story about the origin of the world, B. A tale about the struggle between good and evil, C. A fascinating narrative about the concept of speed, D. A legend about the power of love Correct Option: C
Question 10: What idea can be combined with other mythological themes, such as power or wisdom? Options: A. The concept of love and compassion, B. The idea of speed as a personified concept, C. The theme of competition and rivalry, D. The value of honesty and integrity Correct Option: B
Question 11: What concern can be raised about the fairness of the Myth Olympics' outcome? Options: A. That some competitors are more likable than others, B. That the course is too difficult, C. That Savitar's ability to manipulate the elements and slow down his opponents is unfair, D. That the judges are biased Correct Option: C
Question 12: What aspect of the Myth Olympics can be evaluated for its relevance and impact? Options: A. The characterization of the competitors, B. The themes and messages conveyed in the narrative, C. The accuracy of the mythological references, D. The entertainment value of the event Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about Sleipnir's father, which is a specific question about a mythological character's family relationship. Welcome to another event
in the Myth Olympics— the eternal arena in which 
creatures and deities from global mythologies
compete for glory. I’m Shamash, the Mesopotamian

but this race is the real deal! Our noble competitors will run
the equivalent of 100 marathons through a hazardous
natural obstacle course. And our racers are taking 
their first steps right now! Idaten takes the lead, but don’t let

in the Myth Olympics— the eternal arena in which 
creatures and deities from global mythologies

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Welcome to another event
in the Myth Olympics— the eternal arena in which 
creatures and deities from global mythologies
compete for glory. I’m Shamash, the Mesopotamian
god of judgment, and today we’re gathered to witness 
this year’s clash of stunning speed. Keeping track of our racers with me
is last year’s champion, Hermes— the swift-footed messenger
of the Greek gods. Oh, I'm delighted to hang up my
winged sandals today, Shamash. But I am keeping my helmet on because
we are in for a wild ride! It’s true! Almost every mythical tradition
claims one creature as the fastest of them all. From goddesses who run like the wind
to creatures who outstrip every captor, mortals of all cultures are fascinated
by superhuman swiftness. So, Hermes, who are 
this year’s contestants? Well, the Norse gods have sent Sleipnir— son of Loki and the greatest
of Asgard’s steeds. He’s usually spotted gallivanting
between the realms with Odin. But today, Sleipnir is riding solo. Also competing is Raiju, the Japanese
beast of thunder and lightning. When the weather’s nice, they like
to nap in mortals’ belly buttons. But when clouds darken, Raiju leaps
into action alongside Raijin, the Shinto god of storms. With this fearsome competitor,
lightning can strike at any time. But storms don’t scare Idaten. This Buddhist deity has a record
of outrunning the weather— his name is even part of the Japanese
expression for “run like the wind.” Idaten’s definitely got some tricks
up those steel sleeves. Perhaps, but our last competitor
has tricks of his own. Savitar is the Hindu deity
that sets everything in motion, from moving the Sun
to chasing away sorrow and sickness. Yes, today’s roster contains many
mythic interpretations of speed. From personifications 
of the unpredictable elements to creatures capable of outrunning
reality itself. But perhaps the myth of speed
is really about the elusive nature of all supernatural beings. Those are some, uh, neat ideas, Shamash—
but this race is the real deal! Our noble competitors will run
the equivalent of 100 marathons through a hazardous
natural obstacle course. And our racers are taking 
their first steps right now! Idaten takes the lead, but don’t let
that calm exterior fool you— his determination is legendary. When a literal speed demon stole
one of Buddha's teeth, he raced over mountains and rivers
to capture the culprit. Don’t forget Sleipnir— 
he’s cleared hurdles in his time, too. I’ll say! On his mission to retrieve
Baldur the Bright from the fortress of Hel,
he rode for nine days straight— clearing the gates of the underworld
without breaking a sweat. They don’t call him
the sliding one for nothing— he appears to slide on the wind itself! Of course, wind is often personified
as a sacred being that— No time for a history lesson!
That wind is picking up! Like the force of nature they are, Raiju
brews a storm to scorch the competition. It’s certainly possible. Raiju is known
for their destructive storms. But they’re also our most chaotic racer, frequently crashing to earth and 
getting tangled in flimsy mortal nets. They’re unpredictable! Chaos is often associated
with mythology’s fastest creatures, from the shapeshifting Flemish Kludde
who preys on travelers to the smelly Japanese spirit Nuppeppō
who moves too fast to be caught. True, but there are also steady agents
of speed. Here comes one now! Lending his boundless energy to the Sun,
Savitar breaks through Raiju’s storm! This golden-handed protector of the
universe can manipulate the elements— and all moving things for that matter! A valiant effort to redirect the wind
by Idaten... but not valiant enough. The path seems clear for Savitar. But is that the gallop of hooves I hear? What beautiful blindside! It’s Sleipnir hurtling 
out of another dimension! it seems the shamanic steed shares Odin’s
ability to travel between the realms. This racer might not have to play
by Savitar’s rules. But... wait a second,
am I watching this in slow motion? No! It appears the god of motion is
slowing the speed of his opponent, suspending him centimeters
from the course’s conclusion. Sleipnir’s stampede slows
to a snail’s pace as Savitar leisurely glides
over the finish line! What a finale! Savitar’s mastery of motion
immobilized his fastest foe! It seems Sleipnir’s not too happy
with this controversial result, but hey, there’s always next year. And one might say that we’re all winners
for witnessing the mind-bending speed of so many myths and legends.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Idaten is known for outrunning speed demons in order to retrieve___.
Options: A. The wind, B. The Buddha’s teeth, C. His helmet, D. Sacred shoes
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Welcome to another event
in the Myth Olympics— the eternal arena in which 
creatures and deities from global mythologies
compete for glory. I’m Shamash, the Mesopotamian
god of judgment, and today we’re gathered to witness 
this year’s clash of stunning speed. Keeping track of our racers with me
is last year’s champion, Hermes— the swift-footed messenger
of the Greek gods. Oh, I'm delighted to hang up my
winged sandals today, Shamash. But I am keeping my helmet on because
we are in for a wild ride! It’s true! Almost every mythical tradition
claims one creature as the fastest of them all. From goddesses who run like the wind
to creatures who outstrip every captor, mortals of all cultures are fascinated
by superhuman swiftness. So, Hermes, who are 
this year’s contestants? Well, the Norse gods have sent Sleipnir— son of Loki and the greatest
of Asgard’s steeds. He’s usually spotted gallivanting
between the realms with Odin. But today, Sleipnir is riding solo. Also competing is Raiju, the Japanese
beast of thunder and lightning. When the weather’s nice, they like
